subject: Re: how to transcribe air and ear
msgSnippet: ... theirs. ... That sounds like a very interesting idea you should follow. I might be best just to stick with the vowels so we could get more feedback, since
messageBody:
--- In Read_Alphabet@yahoogroups.com, "Anthony Grahn" <othermale@...>
wrote:

>
> Allow me to suggest example words for each letter from many accents
> and, just as importantly, which letters never to use. And further let me
> propose that the makers of the examples be native speakers of that
> accent and that they can correctly infer Read's intent for each
> letter. I believe incidentally, the group is very well equipped to do
> this. Indeed I imagine everyone reading this post could easily do
theirs.
>


That sounds like a very interesting idea you should follow. I might be
best just to stick with the vowels so we could get more feedback,
since I don't think there is disagreement with the consonants.
However, I am guessing you will get a mixed result. That is, in some
cases, you will discover that a person uses #33 for #34 because of his
dialects, but in others you might find that the member himself is
confused.

Therefore maybe you want to first propose a guide. #32 should be /A/,
according to John Cowan. He has #33 as /O/, and has #34 as /A./ (He
actually has /Q/ for #34, but he describes it as /A./ /Q/ would
something absolutely entirely different, so I think he meant /A./). I
agree with his mapping, but like I have said, that everyone does, or
that others haven't been mixing things up. You might want to describe
the vowels in specific terms. /A/ is with the tongue at the bottom of
the mouth, as when you go to the doctor and say "Ahh." The doctor has
you do this so your tongue is not in the way. Also, your lips are nice
and open, so the doctor can see right in. To me, /A./ sounds a lot
different, but it is really the same exact sound as /A/, but with the
lips rounded. The only way I can describe /O/ is by saying that it is
also prounced like /A./, but with the tongue slightly higher. All
these vowels are pronounced in the back of the mouth.

Though maybe this is not what you had in mind? Maybe you wanted to
determine the letter by the responses, but this is tricky, as I
pointed out above. I think this trickiness is one reason why I want to
use IPA and linguistic definitions; it is much more exact and less
frustrating.

Incidently, I think it is a bit funny that you brought up the "tot" vs
"taught" example. I pronounce these words exactly alike!
